The Valereum Plc board of directors includes:-

James Formolli (Executive Chairman), Gary Cottle (Group CEO), Grant Gischen (Non-Executive Director), Matthew Ripperger (Non-Executive Director), and Simon Brickles (Non-Executive Director).

This composition was established after changes in July 2025, which included the appointment of Gischen and Ripperger, and the departure of Karl Moss and Pete Sekhon from the board.

Based in New York, Ripperger has over 25 years’ experience in investment management and expansive healthcare expertise. He served as managing director at Harbert Stoneview, prior to which he co-headed healthcare investments at TimesSquare Capital and Glenview Capital Management, including serving on the board of Tenet Healthcare. He has also held roles at Smith Barney, UBS Warburg, J.P. Morgan and Citigroup.

Gischen is an experienced venture capital investor and strategic advisor with a global track record across deep tech and the energy transition. He is co-founder and partner at Energy Revolution Ventures (ERV), a UK-based VC firm investing in early-stage technologies in hydrogen and renewable fuels, carbon capture, energy storage and advanced materials. He began his career at Bain & Company, where he supported clients across private equity transactions, digital transformation, energy transition and infrastructure development.

Simon Brickles has officially joined as a Non-Executive Director to the company. Simon Brickles, the current group Chairman of the GSX Group, brings over 30 years’ experience in capital markets. He served as the former head of AIM/London Stock Exchange and other markets.

And some more from AI:-

Yes, Valereum is expected to receive both the $200 million in financing and an annual interest (coupon) payment of $10.5 million.

The agreement is structured as an investment-grade asset-backed financing, a form of debt financing known as Qualified Medium-Term Notes (QMTN) perpetual call certificates.

Key details of the deal:

Principal:

Valereum receives $200 million of funding.

Interest:

Valereum is the recipient of the interest payments, not the payer.

The annual interest is $10.5 million (a 5.25% coupon rate), payable quarterly, which provides a consistent capital inflow to the company.

Consideration:

In return for this capital commitment, Valereum will grant the funding entity, Valereum QGP-SP, a one-year option to purchase up to 49.9% of Valereum's share capital.

The funding is expected to be used for strategic growth initiatives, developing an AI-driven tokenization platform, and pursuing a listing on a U.S. National Exchange.

More from AI:-

Key Details

Parties Involved:

Valereum Plc (a UK-based fintech company) and Valereum QGP-SP (a segregated portfolio company formed under QGP Photonics).

Funding Structure:

The $200 million is provided as investment-grade asset-backed financing (specifically "royalty and streaming capital" via QMTN Perpetual Call Certificates), not traditional debt.

Valereum's Return:

Valereum will receive an annual return of $10.5 million, representing a 5.25% "coupon" from the financing, meaning they receive the income rather than paying interest.

QGP's Option:

In return for the capital commitment, QGP receives a one-year option to acquire up to 49.9% of Valereum's ordinary shares through an equity swap.

Collateral:

The funding is backed by a pool of "royalty and streaming mining assets" which are underwritten by major international rating agencies like S&P and Moody's, providing institutional validation.

Purpose of the Funding

The $200 million funding will be used to advance Valereum's growth and strategic goals.

Key objectives include enhancing its tokenization platform and digital market infrastructure, establishing a Digital Asset Treasury, funding acquisitions and partnerships, and progressing towards a listing on a major U.S. exchange like NASDAQ or NYSE to boost its global profile.

The transaction, announced on November 25, 2025, is expected to close within about four weeks, pending due diligence and regulatory approvals.

The headline figure: The Budget raises taxes by £26bn in 2029-30 - here's how:

Freezing tax thresholds on personal tax and employer National Insurance contributions thresholds for three years from 2028-29 - raising £8bn

Pensions: Taxing salary-sacrificed pensions contributions - £4.7bn

Property, savings and dividends: Increasing the tax rates on dividends, property and savings income by 2 percentage points - £2.1bn

Corporation tax change: Reducing the writing down allowance main rate in corporation tax - £1.5bn

Electric vehicles: A new mileage-based charge on battery electric and plug-in hybrid cars from 2028 - £1.4bn

Gambling: Changes to taxation of gambling - £1.1bn

Reduced capital gains tax relief on disposals to employee ownership trusts - £900m

'Mansion tax': A council tax surcharge on properties worth over £2m - raising £400m

Tax admin and debt collection: Tax administration, compliance and debt collection measures - £2.3bn

Fuel duty: These tax rises are partially offset by a freeze to fuel duty for a further five months, followed by staged increases from 2026, costing £2.4bn next year and £900m each year afterwards

Other taxes: A range of other tax measures, including a Sizewell C levy raise a further £4.4bn
